Discharge Summary:  The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of frequent episodes of tachycardia and dizziness. The initial work-up revealed an atrioventricular block (AVB) with a ventricular rate of 40 bpm. Further evaluation using an ECG showed a complete AVB with ventricular pacing at a rate of 50 ppm.  The patient also had evidence of sinus node dysfunction and sick sinus syndrome (SSS). Ventricular tachyarrhythmia with wide complex tachycardia (WCT) was observed during the admission period.  Subsequently, the patient underwent a dual-chamber pacemaker implantation, which was completed without any complications.  During the hospital stay, the patient had multiple episodes of ventricular tachycardia, which were managed with anti-arrhythmic medications. The patient also had occasional premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) with trigeminy and bigeminy patterns on the ECG.  Further analysis revealed a right bundle branch block (RBBB) and an intermittent first-degree atrioventricular block (AVB) with a type of dysrhythmia known as a primum defect.  After optimizing the medical therapy, the patient's symptoms improved, and stable sinus rhythm was maintained. The patient was discharged with a prescribed medication regimen and a follow-up appointment with the cardiology team in two weeks.

Patient Name: John Doe  Medical Record Number: 12345678  Date of Admission: 05/01/2021  Date of Discharge: 05/07/2021  Diagnosis: Atrioventricular block, Complete  Patient History:  Mr. John Doe, a 67-year-old male, presented to the hospital with complaints of intermittent palpitations, dizziness, and shortness of breath. He had a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He had no history of heart disease or family history of sudden cardiac death.  Hospital Course:  The patient underwent various cardiac investigations, including an electrocardiogram (ECG), Holter monitoring, and echocardiography. The ECG showed a complete atrioventricular block (AVB) with a ventricular rate of 50 bpm. The Holter monitoring revealed episodes of atrial tachyarrhythmias, including a wide complex tachycardia (WCT), ventricular tachycardia (VT), bigeminy, and trigeminy. The echocardiography showed no significant structural abnormalities.  The patient was diagnosed with complete AVB and symptomatic sinus node dysfunction (SSS). He was also found to have an entrant atrial tachyarrhythmia with a WCT, which prompted further evaluation for a possible dual-chamber pacemaker. The patient was started on intravenous medications to control his heart rate and rhythm.  After being stabilized, the patient underwent dual-chamber pacemaker implantation for complete AVB, SSS, and atrial tachyarrhythmia. The pacemaker was programmed in the dual-chamber mode with DDD pacing, and he did not have any complications during the procedure.  The patient was monitored for a few days post-procedure and was eventually discharged home with adequate instructions and follow-up appointments.  Diagnoses:  1. Atrioventricular block, Complete (AVB) 2. Sinus Node Dysfunction (SSS) 3. Entrainment of Atrial Tachycardia (AT) with WCT 4. Dual-chamber Pacemaker Implantation  Impression:  Mr. John Doe was diagnosed with complete atrioventricular block (AVB) with sinus node dysfunction (SSS) and was found to have an entrant atrial tachyarrhythmia with WCT. He underwent successful dual-chamber pacemaker implantation with DDD pacing and had no complications. His discharge was completed with adequate instructions and follow-up appointments.  Additional Findings:  The patient also had a right bundle branch block (RBBB) and primum atrial septal defect (ASD) with mild regurgitation. However, these findings were incidental and were not considered to be significant contributors to his dysrhythmia.

Discharge Summary:   The patient was diagnosed with atrioventricular block (AVB), which was confirmed through an entrant PPM (permanent pacemaker). This AVB was complete, as evidenced by the patient's symptoms of tachyarrhythmia (fast heartbeat), and wct (wide complex tachycardia).  Further evaluation revealed that the patient had sinus node dysfunction, also known as sick sinus syndrome (SSS), and complete heart block (CHB). The patient's rhythm was noted to be a combination of trigeminy and bigeminy, and a primum atrial dysrhythmia was also observed.  A DDD (dual-chamber) pacemaker was implanted to manage the patient's AVB and to maintain a stable heart rate. The patient also had a right bundle branch block (RBBB), which was addressed with medical management. The patient was monitored closely during their hospital stay and had no further episodes of tachycardia or dysrhythmia.  The patient was instructed to continue taking prescribed medication, follow up with their cardiologist as instructed, and to remain mindful of any symptoms or irregular heartbeats. They were also advised to follow a heart-healthy lifestyle, including a healthy diet and regular exercise.  Overall, the patient's management of their AVB and related dysrhythmias was completed successfully, and they were discharged in stable condition with a positive prognosis for future health outcomes.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Atrioventricular block (AVB). The initial workup showed that the AVB was completed, with the entrant rate ranging between 30-40 beats per minute (bpm). Atrial fibrillation (AF) was noted on admission, but the patient was asymptomatic. The patient had a history of sick sinus syndrome (SSS) and chronic heart block (CHB).  Electrophysiologic testing revealed tachyarrhythmia with wide complex tachycardia (WCT) and right bundle branch block (RBBB). The patient was diagnosed with dual chamber pacemaker (DDD) with rate-responsive pacing (RPP). The pacemaker was programmed to avoid tachyarrhythmia and maintain sinus rhythm. The patient also exhibited trigeminy and bigeminy during the testing, which may indicate a possible primum dysrhythmia.  The patient was treated with medications to regulate the heart rhythm and improve symptomatic relief. The patient was discharged with advice to follow up with the cardiologist and monitor the pacemaker setting. The patient was advised to avoid strenuous activity and to adhere to a heart-healthy lifestyle.  Overall, the patient's condition had improved during the hospitalization, and the discharge was successful. The patient was tolerating the medications well, and the pacemaker was functioning optimally. The expectations were good for the patient's long-term outcome, given the comprehensive care and management provided.

Patient Name: John Smith Age: 65 Gender: Male  Diagnosis: Atrioventricular block (AVB), complete Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) Chronic heart block (CHB) Tachyarrhythmia Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome  Presenting Complaint: Mr. John Smith was admitted to the hospital complaining of palpitations and dizziness. He had been experiencing these symptoms for the past few days.  Medical History: Mr. John Smith has a medical history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. He underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery 10 years ago.  Clinical Findings: On examination, the patient had a heart rate of 40 beats per minute (bpm) with an irregular rhythm. The electrocardiogram (ECG) showed atrial fibrillation with complete AVB, WPW syndrome, and right bundle branch block (RBBB). The patient also had tachycardia with ventricular rate of 110 bpm, tacycardia, trigeminy, bigeminy, primum dysrhythmia, and wide complex tachycardia (WCT).  Treatment: The patient was initially managed with intravenous (IV) fluids and anticoagulants. However, due to persistent symptoms, the patient underwent pacemaker implantation. The pacemaker was programmed to DDD mode with a lower rate limit of 60 bpm and upper rate limit of 130 bpm. The patient responded well to the pacemaker and was discharged with a prescription of beta-blockers and anticoagulants.  Discharge Summary: Mr. John Smith was diagnosed with AVB, complete, SSS, CHB, tachyarrhythmia, WCT, WPW syndrome, tacycardia, trigeminy, bigeminy, and primum dysrhythmia. He underwent pacemaker implantation and was treated with beta-blockers and anticoagulants. The patient responded well to the treatment, and his condition improved. He was discharged with instructions to follow up with his cardiologist in two weeks.

Further evaluation showed that the patient also had atrial trigeminy, bigeminy, and a primum dysrhythmia. The patient remained stable throughout the admission period and was discharged with instructions for follow-up care with a cardiologist.  In conclusion, Patient X had a history of CHB, SS, and tachycardia, which resulted in AVB entrant. After being evaluated with an ECG, the patient was diagnosed with a ventricular dysrhythmia, WCT with RBBB. The patient was discharged with a recommendation for continued follow-up with their cardiologist for further management of their AVB and dysrhythmias.

Mr. John Smith, a 62-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital with complaints of worsening shortness of breath, fatigue, and occasional chest pain. After undergoing a series of tests, he was diagnosed with Atrioventricular block (AVB) with complete heart block (CHB) and sick sinus syndrome (SSS). The patient also had a history of tachyarrhythmia, and exhibited premature atrial contractions (PACs) and ventricular dysrhythmia.  Further evaluation revealed that the patient had a Wenckebach-type AVB pattern with entrant atrial pacing (PPM) at a rate of 70 bpm. Additionally, he exhibited frequent episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT), with a wide-complex tachycardia (WCT) and right bundle branch block (RBBB) pattern. The patient also had trigeminy and bigeminy patterns of PACs.  After careful consideration of the patient's symptoms and overall condition, the treatment team opted to move forward with a dual-chamber pacemaker (DDD) implantation. This procedure helped to alleviate the patient's symptoms and restore his heart's proper rhythm.  Overall, Mr. Smith's condition responded well to treatment, with no further tachycardia or dysrhythmia reported upon completion of his hospital stay. He was discharged with instructions to continue monitoring his heart's rhythm to ensure ongoing stability and to report any changes or new symptoms.

Further assessment revealed right bundle branch block (RBBB) and tachycardia. The patient also experienced trigeminy and bigeminy, indicative of recurring rhythm irregularities.  The treatment plan involved the insertion of a permanent pacemaker (PPM) to regulate the heart's rhythm. A dual-chamber PPM was used (DDD), which would control both the atrial and ventricular contractions, ensuring the heart beats at an optimal rate. The procedure was completed without any complications.  The patient was advised to follow-up with their primary care physician regularly and to monitor their heart rate and rhythm for any abnormal patterns. The patient was also advised to avoid activities that could trigger a dysrhythmia. Overall, the patient was discharged in stable condition, with appropriate medications and follow-up instructions provided to ensure adequate management of their condition.

Patient: Mr. Smith Diagnosis: Atrioventricular block (AVB), complete  Summary: Mr. Smith presented to the hospital with symptoms of dizziness, fatigue, and shortness of breath. Upon examination, he was diagnosed with complete atrioventricular block (AVB), a type of heart block where the impulses from the atria cannot pass through to the ventricles.  Further testing showed that Mr. Smith had a history of tachyarrhythmia and supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), which placed him at increased risk for AVB. Additionally, he had sinus node dysfunction (SSS) and chronotropic incompetence (CHB).  Due to the severity of his AVB, Mr. Smith underwent dual chamber pacemaker implantation with atrial entrant PPM (programmable pacemaker) to regulate his heart rate. During the procedure, the medical team noted the presence of right bundle branch block (RBBB) and dysrhythmia, specifically wct and trigeminy bigeminy.  Postoperatively, Mr. Smith was monitored closely for any further dysrhythmia or other complications. His pacemaker parameters were adjusted and titrated to optimal levels, and he was started on a course of anticoagulation therapy.  Overall, Mr. Smith’s treatment for complete AVB was successful, and he tolerated the procedure well. Close follow-up and ongoing monitoring will be necessary to manage any future dysrhythmia or pacing issues.

Discharge Summary  Patient diagnosed with Atrioventricular Block   The patient presented with symptoms of tachyarrhythmia, including wct and persistent tachycardia. Upon further testing, the patient was diagnosed with Atrioventricular Block (AVB), complete. The patient also exhibited symptoms of Sick Sinus Syndrome (SSS), Congenital Heart Block (CHB), and dysrhythmia, including bigeminy and trigeminy.   Treatment included cardiac pacing using a Dual-Chamber Pacemaker (DDP) with a rate-responsive mode and an entrant airway. The procedure was completed without any complications. The patient's cardiac rhythm was monitored post-procedure, and it was noted that the AVB had been corrected, and the patient was able to maintain normal sinus rhythm.   Additionally, the patient was found to have a Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB), which was being monitored. The patient's condition was being managed using medications, including antiarrhythmic drugs and anticoagulants. The patient was advised to follow up with their healthcare provider for further monitoring and management of their condition.   In conclusion, the patient was diagnosed with Atrioventricular Block (AVB), complete, Sick Sinus Syndrome (SSS), Congenital Heart Block (CHB), and dysrhythmia, including bigeminy and trigeminy. Treatment included cardiac pacing using a dual-chamber pacemaker, which was completed without any complications. The patient's condition was being managed using medications, and it was advised to follow up with their healthcare provider for further monitoring and management of their condition.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was diagnosed with Atrioventricular Block (AVB) and treated with permanent pacemaker (PPM) implantation. The AVB was associated with Sick Sinus Syndrome (SSS), Complete Heart Block (CHB), tachyarrhythmia, Wide Complex Tachycardia (WCT), Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB), Trigeminy, and Bigeminy.  The patient underwent AVB Entrant (DDD) pacing mode implantation, and the device was programmed based on the patient's clinical presentation. Atrial (AAI) pacing was completed, and a sensitivity of 2.5 mV was set for the atrial lead. The PPM also monitored for tachyarrhythmia by activating the tachyarrhythmia detection and termination (TDT) function.  The patient experienced several episodes of WCT, which were managed with synchronized cardioversion. The rhythm disturbance was associated with tachycardia, and the PPM was programmed to deliver anti-tachycardia pacing (ATP) to terminate the arrhythmia. The patient also had an episode of Primum (AP) Dysrhythmia, which was managed with atrial pacing.  Overall, the patient was managed successfully with the implantation of a permanent pacemaker. The patient was instructed to follow-up with their physician to ensure continued device function and to monitor for any potential complications. Following a comprehensive evaluation, the patient was deemed safe for discharge.

Discharge Summary:  The patient was diagnosed with Atrioventricular block (AVB) during hospitalization. The AVB was complete, with no electrical impulses passing from the atria to the ventricles. The patient experienced symptoms of syncope and fatigue, which prompted a work-up for heart disease. An electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed sinoatrial (SA) tachycardia with a rate of 112 beats per minute (ppm) and a wide complex tachyarrhythmia (WCT) with ventricular rate of 160 ppm. Cardiac catheterization ruled out coronary artery disease.  Further testing determined that the patient had underlying Sick Sinus Syndrome (SSS) along with Chronic Heart Block (CHB). The patient was experiencing ventricular tachycardia, trigeminy, and bigeminy. The cardiac electrophysiologist recommended implantation of a dual-chamber pacemaker with an AAI (atrial entrant) pacing mode to resolve the sinus node dysfunction. The pacemaker was programmed to operate in a DDD (dual-chamber) mode to maintain AV synchrony.  Post-pacemaker implantation, the patient continued to experience paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). During a tilt-table test, the patient was noted to have orthostatic intolerance and to suffer from primum dysrhythmia. A review of the ECG showed right bundle branch block (RBBB). The pacemaker was adjusted to optimize AV synchronization, and the patient was discharged home with follow-up in the outpatient clinic.  Overall, the patient's AVB and underlying SSS with ventricular tachycardia, trigeminy, and bigeminy were successfully managed with pacemaker placement and adjustment. Further follow-up and close monitoring are recommended to manage the patient's ongoing PSVT and cardiac health.

Patient Name: John Doe  Date of Admission: 01/01/2021  Date of Discharge: 01/05/2021  Diagnosis: Atrioventricular Block  Summary:  John Doe, a 65-year-old male, was admitted to the hospital due to tachyarrhythmia and dysrhythmia. Diagnostic tests revealed a complete AV block, sinus bradycardia, and ventricular tachycardia. Further tests, including the placement of an entrant PPM and an atrial completed SSS, were carried out to manage the patient's condition.  The patient's EKG showed right bundle branch block (RBBB) with a heart rate of 35 beats per minute. The results indicated the presence of trigeminy and bigeminy. A diagnosis of CHB was made, and the patient was started on DDD pacing.  During the hospitalization, the patient remained stable on DDD pacing, without any further episodes of tachycardia or dysrhythmias. The patient's rhythm was monitored throughout the hospitalization, and final testing confirmed that the patient no longer had any tachyarrhythmia or wct.  The patient was discharged in good condition, with close follow-up recommended. The patient was advised to continue taking medications and using the entrant PPM as directed. The patient was also advised to continue follow-up with the cardiologist to manage his condition and prevent any further relapses.

Patient Name: [Name]  Age: [Age]  Diagnosis: - Atrioventricular block (AVB) - Complete heart block (CHB) - Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) - Tachyarrhythmia - Wide complex tachycardia (WCT) - Right bundle branch block (RBBB) - Trigeminy - Bigeminy - Primum atrial septal defect (ASD) - Interatrial block (entrant PPM)  Summary: The patient was admitted to the hospital with a history of dysrhythmia and palpitations. After a comprehensive workup, the patient was diagnosed with multiple cardiac conditions including AVB, CHB, and SSS. Additionally, the patient was noted to have WCT, RBBB, trigeminy, and bigeminy on ECG.  Further investigations revealed a primum ASD, which was likely contributing to the patient's dysrhythmia. An entrant PPM was subsequently inserted, which resolved the patient's AVB.  The patient was closely monitored for several days, during which no further dysrhythmia was identified. A DDD pacemaker was implanted with the aim of managing future episodes of tachycardia and bradycardia.  Overall, the patient's condition improved significantly, and the patient was discharged with instructions for regular follow-up with their cardiologist.

Patient X was admitted to the hospital due to symptoms of tachyarrhythmia and completed heart block (CHB). Based on diagnostic testing, the patient was diagnosed with atrioventricular block (AVB) and sinus node dysfunction (SSS).  During their hospital stay, the patient underwent an electrophysiology study (EPS) which confirmed the presence of AVB and an atrial tachycardia with a wide complex tachycardia (WCT) and ventricular trigeminy. Due to the significant cardiac dysrhythmia, it was decided that a permanent pacemaker (PPM) with dual-chamber pacing (DDD) would be the best course of action for managing the patient's condition.  The implanted PPM was set to a rate-responsive mode with a lower rate limit of 60 bpm and an upper rate limit of 120 bpm in order to prevent episodes of tachycardia. The PPM also included entrant atrial overdrive pacing to reduce atrial dysrhythmia and trigger atrial capture. The device was successfully implanted without complications.  Follow-up monitoring indicated the patient had a right bundle branch block (RBBB) and evidence of both trigeminy and bigeminy. Notably, the patient exhibited a primum-type atrial septal defect, which contributed to their dysrhythmia.  The patient was discharged on medication management and advised to attend regular follow-up appointments with their healthcare provider to continue monitoring their condition.

Patient X was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of atrioventricular block (AVB). This was confirmed by the presence of complete heart block (CHB) on electrocardiogram (ECG). The patient also had a history of tachyarrhythmia, with episodes of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and wide-complex tachycardia (WCT) in the past.  Further investigations revealed that the patient had sinus node dysfunction with sinus bradycardia, supraventricular premature contractions (PACs), and atrial trigeminy on ECG. The patient also had a first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block with a prolonged PR interval, indicating an AV conduction delay.  A dual-chamber pacemaker (DDDR-PPM) was inserted to treat the AVB and associated dysrhythmias. The pacemaker was programmed to deliver atrial pacing to maintain sinus rhythm and prevent atrial entrainment. The device also had a sensing function to detect ventricular tachycardia (VT) and ventricular fibrillation (VF) and deliver appropriate therapy.  The patient's post-operative recovery was uneventful, and the pacemaker was successfully implanted without any complications. The patient was closely monitored for the next few days and had no further episodes of atrial trigeminy, bigeminy or other abnormal rhythms.  In conclusion, Patient X had a complex arrhythmia with multiple dysrhythmias, including AVB, CHB, tachyarrhythmias, and dysrhythmias. The patient was successfully treated with a dual-chamber pacemaker implant (DDDR-PPM) to maintain normal sinus rhythm and prevent further episodes of dysrhythmia. The patient was discharged from the hospital in stable condition with follow-up care to monitor the pacemaker.

Patient: [Name] Diagnosis: Atrioventricular block (AVB), complete  Medical History: The patient presented with a history of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), completed atrial fibrillation (AF), and sick sinus syndrome (SSS). The patient had been implanted with a permanent pacemaker (PPM) with both atrial and ventricular leads in situ.  Clinical Course: Upon presentation, the patient had an electrocardiogram (ECG) that revealed complete AVB with a wide-complex tachyarrhythmia with aberrancy known as ventricular tachycardia (VT) with a right bundle branch block (RBBB) morphology. The patient also had frequent ventricular ectopic beats (VEBs) in trigeminy and bigeminy patterns. The patient was hemodynamically stable but required resuscitation with a synchronized cardioversion for the wide-complex tachycardia (WCT) with evidence of pre-excitation.  The patient was started on intravenous medications for rate control and converted to a narrow-complex sinus rhythm. Given the previous history of SVT, AF, and SSS, a dual-chamber pacemaker with dual-ventricular response and dual-atrial sensing capabilities (DDD) was recommended. The patient underwent successful placement of the pacemaker, which showed appropriate lead positions and sensing.  During follow-up, there was evidence of a primum atrial septal defect (ASD) with right to left shunting, which required further management. The patient also had dysrhythmia with episodes of re-entrant SVT, which were managed with ablation therapy.  Conclusion: The patient with complete AVB with a history of previous SVT, AF, and SSS underwent placement of a permanent pacemaker with dual-chamber and dual-ventricular response capabilities. The patient also had evidence of a primum ASD and dysrhythmia, which were managed with further therapy.
